column4: usually that means you need to turn down your volume software wise
mind if I im you, I've got all the details of the last time i ran through the setup

when I went through the setup on Ubuntu to dual boot it I got to the screen where I allocate the drive space.  It showed my devices in there, I selected /dev/sda which should be the hard drive as a whole.  I said install it said, "No root file system is defined.  Please correct this from partitioning menu"
that is sorta warning you that you will be using the whole harddrive for single boot
ok then which of the devices should I select to get it partitioned?  I also tried to select /dev/sda2 but no luck either, same error
can you take the free space from one of the partitions, and make a new partition with it for ubuntu?
i selected /dev/sda2 and said change the partition size of that one, is that where I would do that?  As I was looking the add button was greyed out at this point
you make one partition smaller, while you make room for a new one
ok when I went in there I can change the size, but the other options is where I got confused in there
what would I want to use the partition as?  It gave me a drop down list of options

when I change the size of the drive to partition, lets say I drop it to 225000 then the left over should become a free partition for me to install ubuntu on?  and if so what do I want to use that partition as when I go into the change menu?
you should see some grey area, and you can create a new ext3 or ext4 partition for that new empty space
the leftover, essentially is nothing, with no partition whatsoever, unless if you create a new one, or expand the old one
ok doesn't matter which one I select then?
ok thank you very much I'm gonna give it another go now
